div.head: The PREFACE.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øty's late Injunctions are the Subject of the following Di≈øcour≈øe: How wi≈øe they are in them≈øelves, and how ≈øuitable to the Exigencies of the Church, is vi≈øible to any one, who is never ≈øo little acquainted with the Di≈øputes of the pre≈øent Age. The Socinians by oppo≈øing the Belief of the Holy Trinity, and the Divinity of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, having brought Religion into Danger, there appear'd Writers of all ≈øorts to defend the Grand and Common Concern of Chri≈øtianity. But they being Men of different Education, Studies, and Inclinations, manag'd the Sacred Controver≈øie in a different way from one another. Some excellently vers'd in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Learning, and great A≈ø≈øertors, as well as Judges of Tradition, ≈øtuck firmly to the Deci≈øions of the Sacred Councils, and the Determinations of the Fathers: Some addicted to the Speculations of the Schools, follow'd a more ab≈øtru≈øe and metaphy≈øical Method: Others us'd to a Philo≈øophical way of arguing, would bring our My≈øteries within the u≈øual and receiv'd Principles of rea≈øoning. But all this was not done with the ≈øame Abilities and Succe≈øs. Some made the Judgment of the Catholick Church before, and after the great Council of Nice, to appear with a va≈øt Clearne≈øs and Evidence: Some did ≈øhew to the learned World, how Grapes may be gather'd of Thorns; and the manner of ≈øpeaking of the Schools become not only plain, but al≈øo florid, and eloquent: Others thought that God had stamp'd in us the Image of his incomprehen≈øible Operations: ∆≤nhappy in this, that they gave to weak Similitudes the Name of Demon≈øtrations, and justly anger'd the pre≈øent, by ridiculing the Terms us'd by the Ancient Church.

This, though indeed well de≈øign'd of all hands, yet met not with all the Succe≈øs which might have been hop'd for. It inflam'd the Socinians, and made them not ≈øo much to weigh the Truth it ≈øelf, as to ≈øtrive to find ≈øome Defect in every one of the≈øe ways. The fir≈øt being mo≈øt Matter of Fact, was very hard to be oppos'd; and who≈øoever reads ≈øeriou≈øly the An≈øwer to the learned Doctor Bull, and is in any degree acquainted with Antiquity, mu≈øt needs wi≈øh for more Exactne≈øs and Candor in the Author of that Writing. The ≈øecond they have profe≈ø≈øedly mi≈øunder≈øtood, owning Dr. South as exact and as clo≈øe a Writer as ever was, to ≈øpeak the Sence of the Church, but willing to mi≈øtake that Sence, and confounding it with Sabelliani≈øm, which the Church ever did, and does now dete≈øt. The third having given them great Advantages, they have crowded one Print upon the neck of another, and the Authority of the Divine Oracles laid a≈øide, Philo≈øophy becomes the Judge of Religion; and Ari≈øtotle or Des Cartes impeach Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles.

But this is not all: Several learned Men among≈øt us could not bear with
the≈øe new Notions, or think their Silence ju≈øtifiable to God and his Church in this Matter: They exprest them≈øelves warmly again≈øt tho≈øe ∆≤ncatholick Terms and Explications, but were an≈øwer'd again with Heat and Clamour; and a War began of a ≈øtrange and unaccountable Nature; all Parties agreeing in the ≈øame De≈øign to maintain our Holy My≈øteries, and yet divided in the way of pur≈øuing it.

The Injunctions obviated all this, by giving a check to a ≈øwarm of Socinian Prints, which with great Industry were di≈øper≈øt over the Kingdom; and obliging Divines not only to treat the≈øe Sacred Matters calmly, but al≈øo to u≈øe no other Expre≈ø≈øions in their Explications, but what the Churches of God have us'd them≈øelves to: A wi≈øe and a truly Chri≈øtian Expedient to pre≈øerve the Peace and ∆≤nity of the Church! For of all the Societies which make up the Catholick Church, none ever pretended to ≈øay any new thing in this Matter; but as they receiv'd the Faith, ≈øo they deliver'd it to us: And to any rational Man, it is a mighty Argument again≈øt Sociniani≈øm, that tho≈øe very Churches which have, and do differ among≈øt them≈øelves in ≈øo many other Points, never differ'd in this; and that the great Variety of Super≈øtructures never in the lea≈øt affected the Foundation.

I hope that this has in a very great mea≈øure laid the Heats rais'd among≈øt us: But it has not ≈øilenc'd the Socinians; th√¥ indeed it appears to me by their late≈øt Prints ≈øince the publi≈øhing of the Injunctions, that they write more out of a de≈øire to have it ≈øaid, that they have left no Book unan≈øwer'd, than really to ≈øatisfie them≈øelves and others concerning tho≈øe ≈øub≈øtantial Arguments, which have been offer'd to them. This is the mo≈øt charitable Con≈øtruction which I can make of the An≈øwers to Mr. Edwards, the Lords Bi≈øhops of Sarum and Chiche≈øter, and the incomparable Vindication of the Lord Bi≈øhop of Worce≈øter. But I think the An≈øwer to my Book to be a ≈øingular In≈øtance of this. A Friend of mine, who is a Gentleman of that Per≈øwa≈øion, had often told me that there was one coming, and I expected it with ≈øome Impatience, de≈øirous to ≈øee what they had to ≈øay to ≈øome plain Arguments, which I thought of great force, and how they would vindicate ≈øo many Places out of their own Books, which they own'd I had cited with a great deal of Truth and Ju≈øtice. At la≈øt my Friend ≈øhews me their late≈øt Collection of An≈øwers, among≈øt which there is one to the four Letters of M. H. de L. I hope it will not be taken ami≈øs if I make ≈øome Remarks upon it.

1. It is very diverting to ≈øee a Writing call'd an An≈øwer to the four Letters; and not ≈øo much as a Page, or Line, or Tittle of the four Letters touch'd. I confe≈øs that this is an ea≈øie way of an≈øwering, and that at this rate any Book upon Earth may be an≈øwer'd. Any Body may have the Plea≈øure to be an Author. But I am not altogether ≈øatisfied, that this is con≈øi≈øtent with that reputation of Learning and Eloquence which the≈øe Gentlemen
men have ≈øo ju≈øtly acquir'd. One or two more ≈øuch An≈øwers, will, I am afraid, ≈øink, or at lea≈øt endanger a part of it.

2. They give a rare rea≈øon for not meddling with the four Letters. I know not, ≈øays the Author, p. 47. whether we are concern'd in them, till I know more certainly in what Sence he holds a Trinity of Divine Per≈øons, and the Divinity and Satisfaction of our Saviour? I beg leave of the≈øe Gentlemen to a≈ø≈øert, that they know as well as I do my ≈øelf, what is my ≈øence in tho≈øe Matters. Ob≈øcurity is none of the many defects which the four Letters may be charg'd with: But they were not willing to intangle them≈øelves in the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of ≈øo many Citations, or to make good the weak ≈øide of their Writings, which they were ≈øen≈øible could not be maintain'd. They have found of late a ≈øhorter Cut; and that is, the famous di≈øtinction of Real and Nominal Trinitarians: They ≈øteal away with this on all occa≈øions, and ≈øtill maintain a running Fight: It is their la≈øt refuge; and had it not been for the rare contrivance, there had been before this an end of the Socinian Controver≈øie. To an≈øwer a ≈øolid Argument, is a hard, and generally an unfortunate Task: But if they can but bring you right or wrong within the Verge of the fatal Di≈øtinction, then they have always a large Field for Di≈øcour≈øe: They act in this like ingenious, but whether altogether like con≈øcientious Men, I am not willing to determine?

3. They are ≈øo full of that beloved di≈øtinction, and ≈øo fond of meeting with any thing that looks like it, that in what they call an An≈øwer to the Four Letters, they have done to them≈øelves and to me a real Injury. To them≈øelves by a flat contradiction in the ≈øpace of four Pages; and to me, by charging me with that which I never ≈øaid or thought: They make me ≈øay that the Divine Per≈øons are Three Infinite Spirits. Pag. 43. He ≈øays Three Infinite Spirits each of them a God, are all of them but One God: I averr that there is nothing in the Four Letters which directly, or indirectly looks like that: It is not the Language of Scripture, nor that of the Catholick Church: It never was, and I hope ≈øhall never be mine. But this they have contradicted, Pag. 47. by de≈øiring to know, in what Sence I hold a Trinity of Divine Per≈øons. One would be apt to ≈øay that this betrays a great deal of Incogitancy.

4. The Four Letters then are ≈øtill ≈øound and ≈øafe; but the Preface is engag'd, and I mu≈øt endeavour to bring it off. Two things in it are excepted again≈øt: The one, that I ≈øaid, That the Con≈øent of the whole Chri≈øtian World mu≈øt be a ≈øtrong Inducement to a mode≈øt Socinian to mi≈øtru≈øt all his Arguments, and that to oppo≈øe all that is great and good in the Church of God in a Point of Faith, which Word the Author of the An≈øwer has overlook'd, is too much for the mo≈øt pre≈øuming Di≈øputant. He ≈øays to this, p. 40. that the ca≈øe is this; one ≈øide has Argument, the other has Authority and Number: And that in a Cla≈øh between Argument
and Number, that whole World, and all that is great in it, when weigh'd again≈øt but one Argument, is as if you had put nothing at all into the Scale.

I ≈øay that he ab≈øolutely mi≈øtakes the Ca≈øe. We maintain that the Church has Rea≈øon, as well as Authority and Number; and that on this very Account a mode≈øt Socinian mu≈øt lo≈øe much of his Confidence. By all that is great and good, I mean the Sacred Councils, the Holy and Learned Fathers, and the different Societies of Chri≈øtians all the World over, who have been baptiz'd in the Name of that Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity, and look upon Ie≈øus Chri≈øt as the Author and Fini≈øher of their Faith. In a Point of Faith, and much le≈øs in the Foundation, God will not ≈øuffer the Catholick Church to err. Had I ≈øaid that it had been a Rea≈øon to a mode≈øt Socinian to mi≈øtru≈øt all his Arguments, I had ≈øaid nothing but what is exactly true: I confe≈øs I was too mode≈øt my ≈øelf in calling it only an Inducement.

5. The other Exception is again≈øt an A≈ø≈øertion, which I thought no Divine in the World would have di≈øputed; That Faith and Rea≈øon are two different things; and, con≈øequently, that that which is the Object of Faith, cannot be the Object of Rea≈øon. He calls this, p. 41. a very ra≈øh Propo≈øition. He ≈øays ≈øome lines before, That the Apo≈øtle teaches, Heb. 11.1. not only that the Object of Faith and Rea≈øon is the ≈øame; but that there cannot be Faith without Rea≈øon; and that Faith is the Product of Rea≈øon. This Author ≈øhould have con≈øider'd, before he call'd the Propo≈øition ra≈øh, that it is the Sence of all the Ancient and Modern Divines; and that th√¥ ≈øometimes Faith and Rea≈øon are conver≈øant about the ≈øame Object; as for in≈øtance, in the Exi≈øtence and ∆≤nity of God, which Rea≈øon con≈øiders as well as Faith; yet for all that, their Object is different, and even in this very ca≈øe, Rea≈øon a≈ø≈øents to it, as it is naturally known; and Faith, as it is ≈øupernaturally reveal'd. The place of the Apo≈øtle ≈øhould not have been mention'd at all. For what is the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , The Evidence of things not ≈øeen, but a Revelation of tho≈øe things which Rea≈øon cannot reach, or penetrate; and on this very account are ≈øaid to be un≈øeen, and is that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that Demon≈øtration, which ri≈øing from an higher Principle, is different from, and has a greater Certainty than Rea≈øon.

But what this Author ≈øays, That there can be no Faith without Rea≈øon, and that Faith is the Product of Rea≈øon, ≈øhews plainly the misfortune of writing An≈øwers in ha≈øte. If by the fir≈øt of the≈øe Propo≈øitions he means that Faith is always rational, and that Rea≈øon never wants ≈øtrong Inducements to believe, which the Schools in their rugged Language call Motives of Credibility, I ≈øay ≈øo too. But if he means, that we cannot believe, except we have a clear Notion of what is propos'd to our Belief; I ≈øay, that it is again≈øt the Nature of Faith, which offers things above Rea≈øon, and expects the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of our Judgments to the Authority of the Revelation.

The ≈øecond Propo≈øition that Faith is the Product of Rea≈øon, is capable of a tolerable Sence, if by it is meant no more, than that Rea≈øon is an introduct ‚Ä¢ on to Faith: But if by it is meant, that it is the Cau≈øe of Faith, I mu≈øt beg this Author's leave to ≈øay, that it is plain Pelagiani≈øm.

6. This Gentleman asks me ≈øeveral Que≈øtions, wherein I mu≈øt take the liberty to tell him that I am not at all concern'd, and con≈øequently not oblig'd to an≈øwer. He argues very ≈ømartly again≈øt Three Infinite Minds, Spirits, or Sub≈øtances; th√¥, at the ≈øame time, I doubt he makes his Adver≈øaries to ≈øay more than really they do. I leave him and them to di≈øpute it; yet one of them I think is a Que≈øtion by no means to be offer'd, and takes off much of the re≈øpect due to the Sacred Writings, p. 42. This therefore, ≈øays he, is the fir≈øt Que≈øtion that I de≈øire Mr. L. to re≈øolve: Will he believe a Doctrine that ≈øeems to imply manife≈øt and inconte≈øtable Contradictions, if ≈øuch Doctrine or Propo≈øition were indeed found in Scripture? To this, I an≈øwer, that the Que≈øtion is unrea≈øonable, becau≈øe the Suppo≈øition on which it is grounded is impo≈ø≈øible. God cannot contradict him≈øelf. A manife≈øt and unconte≈øtable Contradiction in Scripture, is a thing not ≈øo much as to be thought of from him, who is Light, and in whom there is no Darkne≈øs at all. But I well go farther with this Gentleman; and th√¥ I love and honour Rea≈øon as much as any Man in the World, yet I will affirm, that if it were po≈ø≈øible that in any undoubted Scripture there ≈øhould be in clear and expre≈øs Terms a Propo≈øition or Doctrine which ≈øeems to imply a manife≈øt and inconte≈øtable Contradiction, I ought not to reject it, or make my Rea≈øon the Judge of God's Veracity: But my Duty is humbly to re≈øign my ≈øelf to him, and adore what I cannot under≈øtand.

7. I know that this Gentleman will take this very ill; and will ≈øay again, as he has already, p. 41. that I calumniate Rea≈øon, the Light ≈øet up in us by God him≈øelf. But that Light is not given us to impeach and reproach our Maker; and reject what he commands us to believe, or call it a manife≈øt and inconte≈øtable Contradiction, becau≈øe it is above its weak Perceptions: That Light ought to act in its due mea≈øure and proportion; if it goes farther, it is a Rebellion and an Attempt again≈øt the Maje≈øty and Power of God. He calumniates Rea≈øon, who does detract from its Dignity and Energy in tho≈øe things wherein it ought to be Judge. It is an Affront to Rea≈øon to be brought below it ≈øelf: But he al≈øo calumniates Rea≈øon, who exalts it more than it de≈øerves; as he no le≈øs maliciou≈øly injures a Man, who commends in him Qualities which he has not, than he who ob≈øcures and denies tho≈øe which he has. There are ≈øome General Principles wherein Rea≈øon cannot err, and which Man ought to be guided by. None is more plain and evident than this, that he owes his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and a≈ø≈øent to what God propo≈øes: Whether it be comprehen≈øible, or not comprehen≈øible, is no part of the Inquiry? Whether God has propos'd it, is the true ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion? Rea≈øon has a Right to examine, Whether God has propos'd it, or no? The danger of taking things upon Tru≈øt, is too great to deny Rea≈øon the power of examining. But that Point once clear'd, to ≈øay that we ought not to ≈øubmit, becau≈øe it is incomprehen≈øible, or appears to us manife≈øtly contradictory, is an ill and an endle≈øs way of arguing.

8. This Author cannot dige≈øt the Epithets of Narrow and Corrupt, which I gave to Rea≈øon. He complains of it in ≈øeveral places of his ≈ømall Writing. But indeed is not our Rea≈øon ≈øuch? Can he who denies this, pretend that he ever endeavour'd
to know him≈øelf? I have often wonder'd at the pains which ≈øome Men have taken to convince the Oppo≈øers of the Doctrine of Original Sin. The ≈øhorte≈øt and ea≈øie≈øt Method was to ≈øend them to them≈øelves, to find there the fatal con≈øequences of the fir≈øt Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion. I appeal to my ingenious Adver≈øary, who th√¥ certainly a great Ma≈øter of Rea≈øon, yet upon ≈øecond Thoughts will agree with me that the Rea≈øon of the be≈øt Men is very Narrow and Corrupt. Whence do proceed ≈øo many Mi≈øtakes and Errors, Mi≈øapprehen≈øions and Inadvertencies, but from that very Principle? Is not this the Spring of ≈øo many hot and tedious Di≈øputes? And what Rea≈øon but this can be given of ≈øo many Books and Opinions which have divided Mankind?

In this the Excellency of Faith appears, and for this we ought to prai≈øe its Author, the Holy Ie≈øus, that it has rectify'd and improv'd Rea≈øon not only by making it more knowing, but al≈øo more humble, more ≈øincere, and more obedient to God.

I am ≈øure that this is the Method of arguing of the Primitive Fathers in that mighty ≈øtruggle with the Heathen Philo≈øophers, ≈øome of whom did ≈øo exalt Rea≈øon as to pretend to decide of every thing; whil≈øt others did ≈øo revile it, as to be po≈øitive that nothing could certainly be known; and con≈øecrated that wild and extravagant Saying of Socrates, Hoc unum ≈øcio nihil ≈øcio. This I know that I know nothing. Both di≈øputed admirably one again≈øt another.
